arg.name: trig
arg.doc: trigger. Can be any signal. A trigger happens when the signal changes from non-positive to positive.

arg.name: reset
arg.doc: trigger. Resets the list of ugens (`in`) when triggered.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: a demand-rate signal (possibly multi-channel) which is read at each trigger

doc.text:
A UGen which polls results from demand-rate ugens when receiving a trigger. When there is a trigger at the `trig` input, a value is demanded from each ugen in the `in` input and output. The unit generators in the list should be demand-rate. When there is a trigger at the reset input, the demand rate ugens in the list are reset.
Note: By design, a reset trigger only resets the demand ugens; it does not reset the value at Demand's output. Demand continues to hold its value until the next value is demanded, at which point its output value will be the first expected item in the `in` argument.
Note: One demand-rate ugen represents a single stream of values, so that embedding the same ugen twice calls this stream twice per demand, possibly yielding different values. To embed the same sequence twice, either make sure the ugen is demanded only once, or create two instances of the ugen.
'''Warning''': Demand currently seems to have problems with infinite sequences. As a workaround use a very large length instead. E.g. instead of `Dbrown(0, 1, inf)` use `Dbrown(0, 1, 0xFFFFFFFF)`!
'''Warning''': Demand seems to have a problem with initial triggers. For example `Demand.kr(Impulse.kr(0), 1)` will have a spurious zero value output first.

arg.name: dur
arg.doc: the provider of time values. Can be a demand-rate ugen or any signal. The next poll is acquired after the previous duration.

arg.name: reset
arg.doc: a trigger which resets the dur input (if demand-rated) and the the level input ugen. The reset input may also be a demand-rate ugen, in this case providing a stream of reset times.

arg.name: doneAction
arg.doc: a doneAction that is evaluated when the duration stream ends.

arg.name: level
arg.doc: a demand-rate ugen providing the output values.

doc.text: A UGen which polls results from demand-rate ugens in intervals specified by a duration input. A value from the `level` ugen is demanded and output according to a stream of duration values. When there is a trigger at the reset input, the `level` and the `dur` input are reset.

arg.name: dur
arg.doc: the provider of time values. Can be a demand-rate ugen or any signal. The next poll is acquired after the previous duration.

arg.name: reset
arg.doc: a trigger which resets the dur input (if demand-rated) and the the level input ugen. The reset input may also be a demand-rate ugen, in this case providing a stream of reset times.

arg.name: doneAction
arg.doc: a doneAction that is evaluated when the duration stream ends.

arg.name: level
arg.doc: a demand-rate ugen providing the output values.

arg.name: gapFirst
arg.doc: when 0 (default), the UGen does the first level poll immediately and then waits for the first duration value. When this is 1, the UGen initially polls the first duration value, waits for that duration, and then polls the first level (along with polling the next duration value).

doc.text: A UGen which polls results from demand-rate ugens in intervals specified by a duration input, and outputs them as trigger values. A value from the `level` ugen is demanded and output for one sample (when running at audio-rate) or one block (when running at control-rate) according to a stream of duration values. When there is a trigger at the reset input, the `level` and the `dur` input are reset.

arg.name: levels
arg.doc: demand-rate ugen (or other ugen) returning level values

arg.name: durs
arg.doc: demand-rate ugen (or other ugen) returning duration values

arg.name: shapes
arg.doc: demand-rate ugen (or other ugen) returning shape number for the envelope segment.

arg.name: curvatures
arg.doc: demand-rate ugen (or other ugen) returning curvature values. these are used for curveShape segments (shape number 5) and should be zero for other shapes.

arg.name: gate
arg.doc: a control rate gate: if gate is x >= 1, the ugen runs. if gate is 0 > x > 1, the ugen is released at the next level (according to doneAction). if gate is x <= 0, the ugen is sampled and held.

arg.name: reset
arg.doc: a trigger signal. a trigger occurs when passing from non-positive to positive. when the trigger amplitude is < 1, the input ugens (those that are demand-rated) are reset when the current segment ends. if the trigger amplitude is > 1, the reset is performed immediately.

arg.name: levelScale
arg.doc: demand-rate ugen returning level scaling values

arg.name: levelBias
arg.doc: demand-rate ugen returning level offset values

arg.name: timeScale
arg.doc: demand-rate ugen returning time scaling values

arg.name: doneAction
arg.doc: a done action performed when one of the demand-rated series ends

doc.text: An envelope generator UGen using demand-rate inputs for the envelope segments. For each parameter of the envelope (levels, durations and shapes), values are polled every time a new segment starts.

arg.name: length
arg.doc: the number of elements to produces (maybe be infinite)

arg.name: start
arg.doc: the start value of the series

arg.name: step
arg.doc: the incremental step by which the series changes. the step is added to the previous value on each demand.

doc.text:
A demand-rate UGen which produces an arithmetic (linear) series.
The arguments can be constant or any other ugens.

arg.name: length
arg.doc: length of the sequence or `inf`

arg.name: start
arg.doc: initial value

arg.name: grow
arg.doc: factor (multiplier) by which values grow

doc.example: val in = Dgeom(1, 1.2, 15) val tr = Impulse.kr(5) val v = Demand.kr(tr, in) v.poll(tr) val f = v * 30 + 300 SinOsc.ar(f) * 0.1

arg.name: length
arg.doc: length of the sequence or `inf`

arg.name: lo
arg.doc: minimum value (inclusive)

arg.name: hi
arg.doc: maximum value (inclusive)

doc.text: A demand-rate UGen that produces random decimal numbers with a constant spectral density, equivalent to `WhiteNoise` for audio- or control-rate.
doc.example: val in = Dwhite(lo = 0, hi = 15) val tr = Impulse.kr(5) val v = Demand.kr(tr, in) v.poll(tr) val f = v * 30 + 300 SinOsc.ar(f) * 0.1

arg.name: length
arg.doc: length of the sequence or `inf`

arg.name: lo
arg.doc: minimum value (inclusive)

arg.name: hi
arg.doc: maximum value (inclusive)

doc.text: A demand-rate UGen that produces equally distributed random integer numbers.
doc.example: val in = Diwhite(lo = 0, hi = 15) val tr = Impulse.kr(5) val v = Demand.kr(tr, in) v.poll(tr) val f = (v + 62).midicps SinOsc.ar(f) * 0.1

arg.name: length
arg.doc: length of the sequence or `inf`

arg.name: lo
arg.doc: minimum value (inclusive)

arg.name: hi
arg.doc: minimum value (inclusive)

arg.name: step
arg.doc: the maximum step a value can take from the previous value

doc.text: A demand-rate UGen that produces random decimal numbers, analogous to a Brownian motion.
doc.example: val in = Dbrown(lo = 0, hi = 15, step = 1) val tr = Impulse.kr(5) val v = Demand.kr(tr, in) v.poll(tr) val f = v * 30 + 300 SinOsc.ar(f) * 0.1

arg.name: length
arg.doc: length of the sequence or `inf`. This is currently (SuperCollider 3.7.2) broken, and the sequence always has infinite length.

arg.name: lo
arg.doc: minimum value (inclusive)

arg.name: hi
arg.doc: maximum value (inclusive)

arg.name: step
arg.doc: the maximum step a value can take from the previous value

doc.text:
A demand-rate UGen that produces random integer numbers, analogous to a Brownian motion, or the `drunk` object in Max.
'''Note''': The `length` parameter seems currently broken.
doc.example: val in = Dibrown(lo = 0, hi = 15, step = 2) val tr = Impulse.kr(5) val v = Demand.kr(tr, in) v.poll(tr) val f = (v + 62).midicps SinOsc.ar(f) * 0.1

arg.name: repeats
arg.doc: The number of repetitions of the entire sequence

arg.name: seq
arg.doc: A multi-channel signal providing the values at each step of the sequence. Typically (but not necessarily) a sequence of constant values.

doc.text:
A demand-rate UGen which reproduces and repeats a sequence of values.
The arguments can be constant or any other ugens, where demand rate UGens are normally polled, proceeding to the next value when the sub-sequence ends.
doc.example: val in = Dseq(Seq(3, 5, 7, 8, 11), inf) val tr = Impulse.kr(5) val v = Demand.kr(tr, in) v.poll(tr) val f = (v + 62).midicps SinOsc.ar(f) * 0.1

example.name: constants alternating with white noise samples

doc.example: val in = Dseq(Seq[GE](3, 5, 7, 8, 11, WhiteNoise.kr * 2), inf) val tr = Impulse.kr(5) val v = Demand.kr(tr, in) v.poll(tr) val f = (v + 62).midicps SinOsc.ar(f) * 0.1

example.name: constants alternating with two brownian values

doc.example: val br = Dbrown(lo = -3, hi = 3, step = 1, length = 2) val c7 = Dseq(7, repeats = inf) val in = Dseq(Seq[GE](3, 5, 7, 8, 11, br), inf) val tr = Impulse.kr(5) val v = Demand.kr(tr, in) v.poll(tr) val f = (v + 62).midicps SinOsc.ar(f) * 0.1

arg.name: repeats
arg.doc: The number of items polled from the sequence

arg.name: seq
arg.doc: A multi-channel signal providing the values at each step of the sequence. Typically (but not necessarily) a sequence of constant values.

doc.text:
A demand-rate UGen which reproduces and repeats values of a sequence. It is very similar to `Dseq`, the difference being that the `repeats` parameter specifies the length of output sequence, not the number of repetitions of the input sequence. The input sequence is repeated if `repeats` is greater than the length of the input sequence.
The arguments can be constant or any other ugens, where demand rate UGens are normally polled, proceeding to the next value when the sub-sequence ends.
doc.example: val in = Dseq(Seq(3, 5, 7, 8, 11), 8) val tr = Impulse.kr(5) val v = Demand.kr(tr, in) v.poll(tr) val f = (v + 62).midicps SinOsc.ar(f) * 0.1

arg.name: buf
arg.doc: the identifier of the buffer to read out

arg.name: index
arg.doc: the frame index into the buffer

arg.name: loop
arg.doc: whether to wrap an exceeding phase around the buffer length (1) or not (0)

doc.text: A demand-rate UGen that reads out a buffer. All inputs can be either demand UGens or any other UGens.

arg.name: repeats
arg.doc: The number of items polled from the sequence

arg.name: seq
arg.doc: A multi-channel signal providing the values at each step of the sequence. Typically (but not necessarily) a sequence of constant values.

doc.text: A demand-rate UGen which outputs random elements from a sequence. `Drand` allows duplicate elements to appear, whereas `Dxrand` forbids repetitions.
doc.example: val in = Drand(Seq(3, 5, 7, 8, 11), inf) val tr = Impulse.kr(5) val v = Demand.kr(tr, in) v.poll(tr) val f = (v + 62).midicps SinOsc.ar(f) * 0.1

arg.name: repeats
arg.doc: The number of items polled from the sequence

arg.name: seq
arg.doc: A multi-channel signal providing the values at each step of the sequence. Typically (but not necessarily) a sequence of constant values.

doc.text: A demand-rate UGen which outputs random elements from a sequence. `Dxrand` forbid repetitions, whereas `Drand` allows duplicate elements to appear.
doc.example: val in = Dxrand(Seq(3, 5, 7, 8, 11), inf) val tr = Impulse.kr(5) val v = Demand.kr(tr, in) v.poll(tr) val f = (v + 62).midicps SinOsc.ar(f) * 0.1

arg.name: repeats
arg.doc: The number of repetitions of the entire sequence

arg.name: seq
arg.doc: A multi-channel signal providing the values at each step of the sequence. Typically (but not necessarily) a sequence of constant values.

doc.text: A demand-rate UGen which outputs a randomly shuffled version of an input sequence. The sequence is only shuffled once, thus when `repeats` is greater than one, the same randomized sequence will be repeated, until the UGen is reset. This happens for example, when it is nested inside a `Dseq`, as shown in the example "reshuffle".
doc.example: val in = Dshuf(Seq(3, 5, 7, 8, 11), inf) val tr = Impulse.kr(5) val v = Demand.kr(tr, in) v.poll(tr) val f = (v + 62).midicps SinOsc.ar(f) * 0.1
val in = Dseq(Seq[GE](Dshuf(Seq(3, 5, 7, 8, 11), 4), 24), inf) val tr = Impulse.kr(5) val v = Demand.kr(tr, in) v.poll(tr) val f = (v + 62).midicps SinOsc.ar(f) * 0.1
val in = Dseq(Seq(Dshuf(Seq.fill(81)(util.Random.nextInt(10)), 5)), inf) val tr = Impulse.ar(500) val f = Demand.ar(tr, in) * 30 + 340 SinOsc.ar(f) * 0.1

val in = Dseq(repeats = inf, seq = Dshuf(repeats = 8, seq = Seq[GE]( Drand(Seq(1, 2, 3), 1), 3, Drand(Seq(20, 23, 56), 1), 7, 8.5))) val tr = Impulse.kr(MouseX.kr(1, 40, 1)) val f = Demand.kr(tr, in) * 30 + 340 SinOsc.ar(f) * 0.1

arg.name: in
arg.doc: a demand-rate UGen, producing values which are passed through, and which will be reset by this UGen

arg.name: reset
arg.doc: a demand-rate or any other UGen. When crossing from non-positive to positive, `Dreset` resets its `in` argument.

doc.text: A demand-rate UGen that, when triggered, resets the state of its `in` argument.
doc.example: val in = Dreset(Dseries(0, 2, inf), MouseButton.kr) val tr = Impulse.kr(5) val v = Demand.kr(tr, in) v.poll(tr) val f = v * 30 + 340 SinOsc.ar(f) * 0.1

arg.name: in
arg.doc: the signal you want to poll

arg.name: trigID
arg.doc: if greater then 0, a `"/tr"` OSC message is sent back to the client (similar to `SendTrig`)

arg.name: run
arg.doc: if 1 the polling is active, if 0 it is inactive.

arg.name: label
arg.doc: a string or symbol to be printed with the polled value

doc.text: A demand rate UGen printing the current output value of its input to the console when polled.
